awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Carbon dioxide (CO2) fixation into cellulosic textile products through heteropolymer stabilization of enzymes in cell-free synthesis
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I proposal is in the development of a new carbon utilization technology with the ability to make high-value, essential products from carbon dioxide (CO2) like cellulosic textiles, food, and building materials. Enzymatic carbon utilization is of high interest due to its ability to make high-value natural products from carbon dioxide. The impediment to enzymatic carbon utilization technology has been the short longevity of both enzymes and input molecules under cell-free industrial conditions. This project will yield a novel enzyme stabilization approach for carbon fixation and synthesis enzymes. The resulting system may unlock CO2 as a new, natural resource for essential product supply chains that are carbon-negative and water- and land-neutral, unlocking a $10 trillion global market. This scalable technology could create a new carbon industry and advance manufacturing jobs in the United States. This technology could enable sustainable and domestic production of America’s most essential materials from waste carbon dioxide emissions at a cheaper cost than today’s production.

This project involves a production method that applies a bio-inspired, non-covalent enzyme stabilization strategy that employs cell-free conversion of carbon emissions into cellulosic fibers for textiles in a CO2-to-textile process over industrially relevant time periods. The proposed stabilization method preserves enzyme conformation without harming baseline activity to allow for enzymatic activity in non-natural environments. The heteropolymers are synthesized using a standard reversible addition-fragmentation chain transfer (RAFT) polymerization approach to produce disordered polymeric chains with diverse monomers of varying charges and hydrophilicity/hydrophobicity characteristics to complement and stabilize enzymes surfaces. The disordered nature of the polymers enables local surface binding to stabilize the enzyme, maintaining its conformation and protecting against denaturing or degradation. The project scope covers key technical hurdles: (1) the development of a enzyme stabilization technique for carbon fixation and synthesis enzymes, (2) the development of a carbon conversion system and process in a non-natural, industrial environment, and (3) confirmation of a full proof-of-concept solution that can be scalable from mL to 50L scale. If successful, the result is an effective enzyme stabilization method that can fix carbon emissions under cell-free conditions for use in industrial supply chains.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Outcomes: In this Small Business Innovation Research Phase I project, Rubi's early project findings revealed a strategic shift towards enzyme immobilization, with a focus on optimizing the expression and stabilization of key enzymes and fostering partnerships for high-throughput screening to increase expression yield and screen diverse immobilization techniques. 

Upon embarking on our Phase I project, our team delved into molecular modeling of two key pathway enzymes. The experiments focused on identifying hydrophobic, hydrophilic, and charged, regions on these enzymes to guide the synthesis of random heteropolymers (RHPs) for effective enzyme stabilization in industrial process conditions. However, early insights indicated potential challenges with RHPs (including challenges related to cellulose product separation and the stability of multimeric enzymes in non-native industrial conditions), necessitating a strategic shift in our approach. We then expanded our enzymologist team, gathered additional resources including a new lab space, and begin exploring various immobilization techniques, including cross-linked enzyme aggregates, covalent attachments, ionic interactions, and absorbent stabilization methods. 

These next experiments uncovered complexities in single-point and multi-point attachment methods, emphasizing the need for method optimization and broader substrate screening. This valuable learning extends to other enzymes in our process, enhancing our understanding of enzyme immobilization for industrial conditions across our enzymatic pathway. Although one major Phase I accomplishment was successfully constructing a full proof-of-concept CO2-to-cellulose cascade, the process required various workarounds, prompting a strategic shift towards enhancing efficiency and robustness before advancing to scale. Our Phase I journey, while shifting focus to a broader enzyme immobilization strategy, has been pivotal in laying a robust foundation for our growing technology.  

As we transition to Phase II, our trajectory emphasizes high-throughput screening partnerships for enzyme immobilization optimization and continued efforts in increasing key enzyme expression, operational stability, and activity. Collaborations for these screenings are anticipated by the end of 2023. Our Phase II objectives include evaluating flue gas samples from manufacturing partners, monitoring enzyme activity and CO2 consumption rates, scaling a bench-scale process for continuous production, and assessing cellulose quality as we scale. After the conclusion of Phase II, we also envision deploying pilot-scale Rubi reactors at manufacturing sites, substantially reducing carbon emissions and creating novel tree-free cellulosic materials.  

Intellectual Merit: This Small Business Innovation Research Phase I project establishes Rubi's pioneering CO2-to-cellulose technology, inspired by nature's own Calvin Cycle, responding to a critical global need for carbon reduction solutions. Our innovation converts CO2 into high-demand materials, such as cellulose, with line-of-sight cost neutrality at scale and minimal water and land usage. The "tree-free" cellulose production process challenges existing norms in both carbon capture industrial and cellulosic materials sectors, eliminating the need for costly and energy-intensive gas separation, raw materials transportation, traditional sourcing (including deforestation), and the energy- and chemically intensive processing of raw materials. Rubi has been able to overcome the limitations of incumbent materials and technologies through a novel multi-enzymatic synthetic cascade, pushing the boundaries of interdisciplinary science and state-of-the-art engineering. While existing academic research has primarily focused on isolated components of the Rubi process, such as the individual RuBisCo enzyme, our complex cell-free multi-enzyme transformation process represents a scientific advancement, showcasing the research's innovative spirit and transformative impact. This Phase I exploration extends beyond the conventional realms of carbon capture and utilization, biological synthesis, and sustainable textile engineering, charting new territory that bridges multiple domains into a single technology. 

Broader Impacts: Rubi is tackling the dual challenges of decarbonizing the textile manufacturing industry and its associated supply chains, and creating sustainable materials derived directly from CO2. Rubi's technology replicates the biosynthetic processes that occur within plants to directly synthesize cellulose from CO2, but without the need for land, water, and energy-intensive of removing and breaking down carbon sinks (i.e., trees) to do so. In its initial phase, Rubi is dedicated to scaling this pioneering technology to capture CO2 from manufacturing facility flue gas and produce low-carbon-footprint cellulosic textiles for the fashion industry (the 3rd-most CO2-polluting supply chain on the planet, producing 10% of all humanity's carbon emissions). Aligning with the DOE's Technology Readiness Level Scale for Carbon Capture Large-Scale Pilot Projects, we estimate our demonstration scale CO2 capture to be 1000 metric tons CO2/year. However, Rubi's advancements lay the foundation for reducing the carbon footprint in diverse manufacturing sectors, paving the way for a more sustainable future across multiple industries, including building materials, proteins, foods, and packaging. Lastly, driven by the founders' enthusiasm to support entrepreneurship among historically excluded individuals and to foster student interest in cutting-edge biotechnology, Rubi collaborated with UC Berkeley to allow exchange students from Chalmers University (Sweden) to join Rubi during their summer business course.  As we enter our Phase II proposal period, Rubi looks forward to sustaining a program focused on student outreach and engagement within the vibrant academic and industry community of the Bay Area. 


Last Modified: 11/17/2023
Modified by: Neeka Mashouf
